questions.text: Light pencil is fine for Exam 1 if your handwriting is neat.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned for marking. Light pencil often doesn't scan clearly. Use a dark pen or 2B pencil minimum.
questions.studyTip: Dark ink or 2B pencil—assessors mark scanned images, not your paper.

questions.text: Assessors mark scanned images, so dark writing is essential for readability.
questions.explanation: Your paper is scanned before marking. Faint writing may be misread or missed entirely.
questions.studyTip: If in doubt, go darker. Faint work costs marks.

questions.text: For multi-mark questions, you can skip intermediate steps if the final answer is correct.
questions.explanation: Full marks require clear, logical working. Omitting steps or abbreviating working loses method marks even with a correct answer.
questions.studyTip: No working = no marks, even if the answer is right.

questions.text: Showing each algebraic step allows you to earn partial marks even with arithmetic errors.
questions.explanation: Method marks reward correct approach. A small arithmetic slip with good working still earns most marks.
questions.studyTip: Write every step. Partial credit comes from visible method.

concepts.title: No CAS means manual skills matter

questions.text: In Exam 1, algebraic and arithmetic errors are rare since students can check on calculators.
questions.explanation: Exam 1 has no CAS or calculator. Algebraic and arithmetic errors are common. You must be confident with manual computation.
questions.studyTip: Practise without CAS. Exam 1 tests your hand computation skills.

questions.text: Exam 1 requires strong manual algebra and arithmetic since no technology is permitted.
questions.explanation: You only have the formula sheet. All manipulation, differentiation, and integration must be done by hand.
questions.studyTip: Drill integration, differentiation, and algebra by hand before Exam 1.

questions.text: Memorising all formulas is essential since the formula sheet only has basic ones.
questions.explanation: The formula sheet contains key formulas—use it. But you must apply them correctly. Some students misuse formulas or apply them to wrong contexts.
questions.studyTip: Know what's on the sheet and practise applying each formula correctly.

questions.text: The formula sheet is helpful, but you must know how to apply each formula appropriately.
questions.explanation: Having the formula isn't enough. You need to recognise when to use it and substitute values correctly.
questions.studyTip: Practise using the formula sheet under timed conditions.

questions.text: Messy handwriting is fine as long as your mathematical working is correct.
questions.explanation: Assessors must read your work. Illegible digits, unclear symbols, or ambiguous notation can cost marks.
questions.studyTip: Clear digits, clear symbols. If they can't read it, they can't mark it.

questions.text: Making sure digits like 4 and 9, or 1 and 7, are clearly distinguishable prevents lost marks.
questions.explanation: Similar-looking digits cause misreading. Take care with formation, especially under time pressure.
questions.studyTip: Slow down for final answers. A misread digit means a wrong mark.

questions.text: Pencil is acceptable throughout Exam 2 since you have access to CAS.
questions.explanation: Section B extended answers should be in pen. Pencil often scans poorly. Use pencil only for graphs and diagrams.
questions.studyTip: Pen for written work, pencil for graphs. Both must be dark.

questions.text: Writing Section B responses in dark pen ensures they scan clearly for assessors.
questions.explanation: Scanned images are marked. Ink shows up reliably; pencil can fade or blur.
questions.studyTip: Dark blue or black ink for Section B. Check your pen works before the exam.

concepts.title: Answers in exact form unless specified

questions.text: You should always give decimal approximations for cleaner presentation.
questions.explanation: Unless decimal places are specified, give exact answers. Writing 0.333 instead of ⅓ or 1.414 instead of √2 loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Exact form unless told otherwise. π stays as π, not 3.14.

questions.text: Leave answers in exact form like √2 or π unless the question specifies decimal places.
questions.explanation: Exact answers show mathematical precision. Only round when explicitly instructed.
questions.studyTip: Check: does it say 'correct to 2 decimal places'? If not, stay exact.

questions.text: A correct final answer without working will earn full marks for any question.
questions.explanation: Answers without supporting work won't earn method marks. The mark allocation indicates detail required.
questions.studyTip: 3 marks = 3 things to show. Match your response to the marks available.

questions.text: The number of marks indicates how much working and detail is expected in your response.
questions.explanation: A 1-mark question needs a brief answer. A 4-mark question requires substantial working.
questions.studyTip: Low marks = concise. High marks = show your method step by step.

questions.text: Skimming questions quickly is fine since most follow predictable patterns.
questions.explanation: Many students lose marks by not responding to all parts of questions. Small details matter: 'in terms of Q', 'including endpoints', 'verify the smooth join'.
questions.studyTip: Read twice. Underline key instructions. Answer exactly what's asked.

questions.text: Reading every word of a question helps you avoid missing specific requirements.
questions.explanation: Questions often have precise conditions: express in a certain form, include specific features, verify particular properties.
questions.studyTip: Circle command words: 'show', 'verify', 'express in terms of', 'hence'.

questions.text: CAS can do everything, so you don't need to understand the mathematics behind it.
questions.explanation: CAS helps with computation, but you must set up problems correctly. Understanding the mathematics guides your CAS use.
questions.studyTip: CAS executes your plan—you still need to know what to ask it.

questions.text: CAS is a powerful tool, but you must know how to set up problems and interpret output.
questions.explanation: Strong students use CAS to check work, explore solutions, and handle tedious computation. They still understand the method.
questions.studyTip: Use CAS for cross products, integrals, and solving—but know what you're doing.

questions.text: Copying answers from your CAS screen is straightforward and error-free.
questions.explanation: Transcription errors are common. Students misread displays, miss digits, or copy wrong lines. Double-check what you write.
questions.studyTip: Read the CAS output twice before writing. One wrong digit ruins everything.

questions.text: Carefully checking when transferring answers from CAS to paper prevents careless errors.
questions.explanation: Many marks are lost to transcription mistakes. Verify before writing your final answer.
questions.studyTip: Copy slowly. Check digits match. Better slow and right than fast and wrong.

questions.text: Small algebraic errors are usually overlooked if your method is correct.
questions.explanation: Algebraic errors propagate through your working and lead to wrong answers. Careful manipulation is essential, especially in Exam 1.
questions.studyTip: Check each line. Errors multiply—one slip can derail everything.

questions.text: Taking care with signs, brackets, and factorisation prevents cascading errors.
questions.explanation: Most algebraic errors come from sign mistakes, missing brackets, or incorrect expansion. Slow down for accuracy.
questions.studyTip: Brackets are your friends. When in doubt, add more brackets.

questions.text: When differentiating y² with respect to x, you can write 2y without any additional factors.
questions.explanation: By the chain rule, d/dx(y²) = 2y · dy/dx. Forgetting the dy/dx factor is a common error.
questions.studyTip: Every y term needs dy/dx attached. That's the chain rule in action.

questions.text: Implicit differentiation requires applying the chain rule when differentiating terms containing y.
questions.explanation: Since y depends on x, differentiating y² gives 2y(dy/dx). This dy/dx factor is essential.
questions.studyTip: d/dx(yⁿ) = n·yⁿ⁻¹·(dy/dx). Never forget that last factor.

questions.text: The derivative of f(x)g(x) is simply f'(x)g'(x).
questions.explanation: The product rule states: d/dx[f(x)g(x)] = f'(x)g(x) + f(x)g'(x). Multiplying derivatives is wrong.
questions.studyTip: Product rule: (uv)' = u'v + uv'. Two terms, not one.

questions.text: Using the product rule correctly gives f'(x)g(x) + f(x)g'(x) for the derivative of a product.
questions.explanation: Each function takes a turn being differentiated while the other stays as is. Add the results.
questions.studyTip: Differentiate first × keep second + keep first × differentiate second.

questions.text: Writing ∫f(x) without dx is acceptable shorthand in exams.
questions.explanation: A proper integral statement must include dx. Omitting it is incorrect mathematical notation.
questions.studyTip: No dx, no integral. It's not optional—it's part of the notation.

questions.text: Every integral must include the differential, such as ∫f(x)dx, to be mathematically correct.
questions.explanation: The dx indicates the variable of integration. It's required for proper notation.
questions.studyTip: Write the dx every single time. Build the habit.

questions.text: When setting up a definite integral for a curve, any reasonable limits will give the same answer.
questions.explanation: Integration terminals must match the domain specified in the question. Using wrong limits (e.g., 0 to 2 instead of 1 to 2) gives wrong answers.
questions.studyTip: Read the question. The terminals come from the problem context, not guesswork.

questions.text: Checking that integration terminals match the question requirements prevents errors.
questions.explanation: Common errors include using parameter limits instead of variable limits, or misreading the bounds.
questions.studyTip: Before integrating: what are my limits? Double-check against the question.

questions.text: In integration by parts, it doesn't matter which function you choose to differentiate or integrate.
questions.explanation: Choosing incorrectly makes the integral harder, not easier. Generally differentiate polynomials/logs, integrate exponentials/trig.
questions.studyTip: LIATE order: Log, Inverse trig, Algebraic, Trig, Exponential—differentiate from left.

questions.text: Selecting the right function to differentiate in integration by parts simplifies the process.
questions.explanation: Good choices reduce complexity. Pick the function that simplifies when differentiated.
questions.studyTip: If differentiation makes it simpler, that's your u.

questions.text: You can often find antiderivatives by inspection without explicit substitution.
questions.explanation: While sometimes possible, explicit substitution is more reliable. Students who skip substitution often make errors.
questions.studyTip: When in doubt, write out the substitution. Inspection fails more often than you think.

questions.text: Writing out substitution steps explicitly leads to more reliable integration.
questions.explanation: Clear substitution with u = ..., du = ... reduces errors and shows method for partial credit.
questions.studyTip: Show u and du explicitly. It takes seconds and saves marks.

questions.text: After antidifferentiating, you can leave the variable in your final answer for a definite integral.
questions.explanation: A definite integral evaluates to a number. Leaving x or t in your answer shows incomplete evaluation.
questions.studyTip: Definite integral = number. If you still have a variable, you're not done.

questions.text: Definite integrals must be fully evaluated by substituting limits to give a numerical answer.
questions.explanation: Substitute upper limit, subtract lower limit value. The answer is a number, not an expression.
questions.studyTip: [F(x)]ₐᵇ = F(b) − F(a). Finish the job.

questions.text: Acceleration is always just the second derivative of position: a = d²x/dt².
questions.explanation: While true, alternative forms are often needed. When velocity is given as v(x), use a = v(dv/dx). Students often forget this form.
questions.studyTip: a = dv/dt = d²x/dt² = v(dv/dx). Know all three forms.

questions.text: When velocity is given as a function of position, use a = v(dv/dx) to find acceleration.
questions.explanation: This form is essential when time isn't explicitly involved. Many students only know a = dv/dt.
questions.studyTip: v = f(x)? Use a = v(dv/dx). Don't try to find t first.

questions.text: Limits are always evaluated by direct substitution.
questions.explanation: Direct substitution often gives 0/0 or ∞/∞. You may need to factorise, rationalise, or apply L'Hôpital's rule.
questions.studyTip: If substitution gives 0/0, more work is needed. Simplify first.

questions.text: When direct substitution gives an indeterminate form, algebraic manipulation is needed before evaluating.
questions.explanation: Factor and cancel, multiply by conjugates, or split fractions. Only substitute after simplification.
questions.studyTip: 0/0 means simplify. Divide by highest power or factorise.

questions.text: A rough sketch is sufficient as long as the general shape is correct.
questions.explanation: Accurate graphs are required. Turning points, intercepts, and endpoints must be precisely positioned.
questions.studyTip: Use the grid. Plot key points exactly, then draw smooth curves through them.

questions.text: Graphs should have turning points and intercepts positioned accurately on the provided grid.
questions.explanation: Use your CAS to get exact coordinates. Then plot carefully on the grid provided.
questions.studyTip: Sketch on CAS first with matching domain/range, then transfer precisely.

questions.text: Graphs can touch or cross their asymptotes as long as they eventually approach them.
questions.explanation: Graphs must approach asymptotes without crossing (for vertical) or touching (at limiting values). Show the curve getting closer but never reaching.
questions.studyTip: Asymptotes are barriers. Curve approaches but never reaches or crosses.

questions.text: Graphs of rational functions must show curves approaching but never touching asymptotes at extremes.
questions.explanation: Asymptotic behaviour means the curve gets infinitely close. Show this clearly near the asymptote.
questions.studyTip: Draw asymptotes as dashed lines. Make the curve 'hug' them at the edges.

questions.text: Drawing asymptotes as dashed lines is enough—you don't need to label them.
questions.explanation: Asymptotes should be labelled with their equations (e.g., x = 2 or y = 3). Unlabelled lines may not earn marks.
questions.studyTip: Draw it dashed, then write its equation next to it.

questions.text: Every asymptote on your graph should be drawn as a dashed line and labelled with its equation.
questions.explanation: This shows you understand what the asymptote represents, not just where it is.
questions.studyTip: Vertical asymptote x = a. Horizontal asymptote y = b. Always label.

questions.text: When sketching an ellipse, connecting the intercepts with any smooth curve is acceptable.
questions.explanation: Ellipses have specific curvature. They should be vertical at one axis and horizontal at the other. Many students draw curves that aren't truly elliptical.
questions.studyTip: At the x-intercept, curve is vertical. At the y-intercept, curve is horizontal.

questions.text: A quarter ellipse should be vertical at one intercept and horizontal at the other.
questions.explanation: This follows from the tangent directions. The curve transitions smoothly between these orientations.
questions.studyTip: Think of the tangent at each end. The curve must match those directions.

questions.text: Sketching rational functions only requires showing asymptotes and a general curve shape.
questions.explanation: You need asymptotes (labelled), intercepts, correct behaviour in each region, and the curve passing through correct points.
questions.studyTip: Find asymptotes, intercepts, and sign in each region. Then sketch.

questions.text: Rational function sketches need asymptotes, intercepts, and correct behaviour in each region.
questions.explanation: The curve must be in the right quadrant for each section and approach asymptotes correctly.
questions.studyTip: Test a point in each region to check if y is positive or negative.

questions.text: All curves pass through intercepts at the same angle.
questions.explanation: Curves may flatten near intercepts (like y = x³ at origin) or pass through at an angle. The behaviour depends on multiplicity of roots.
questions.studyTip: Double root = touches and turns. Triple root = flattens through.

questions.text: Graphs with higher multiplicity roots flatten near those intercepts.
questions.explanation: A double root means the curve touches and turns. Higher multiplicities show more flattening.
questions.studyTip: Know how multiplicity affects the curve at each root.

questions.text: For 'show that' questions, writing the given answer and working backwards is acceptable.
questions.explanation: 'Show that' requires forward logical progression from given information to the stated result. Working backwards isn't showing—it's verifying.
questions.studyTip: Start from what you're given. End at what you must show. Every step forwards.

questions.text: 'Show that' questions require clear logical steps leading from given information to the stated result.
questions.explanation: Each step must follow from the previous. The assessor traces your logic from start to finish.
questions.studyTip: Think: 'Because of this... therefore that... hence the result.'

questions.text: If the algebra is straightforward, you can jump to the final result in a 'show that' question.
questions.explanation: Even simple steps must be written. The purpose is to demonstrate understanding, not just get the answer.
questions.studyTip: Write every line. 'Obvious' to you isn't obvious to an assessor.

questions.text: Every algebraic step in a 'show that' question should be explicitly written, even if simple.
questions.explanation: You're being assessed on the process. Omitted steps suggest you're copying the answer, not deriving it.
questions.studyTip: More steps = more evidence of understanding = more marks.

concepts.title: Arrive at the exact form given

questions.text: In 'show that' questions, your final expression can be equivalent to the given answer in a different form.
questions.explanation: You must arrive at exactly the form stated. If it says 'show that y = 2x + 3', writing y = 3 + 2x might lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Match the exact form given. Rearrange to reach their expression precisely.

questions.text: Your final line in a 'show that' question should match exactly the expression given in the question.
questions.explanation: The given form is part of the question. Your derivation should conclude with that exact expression.
questions.studyTip: End with: '... = [exact expression from question]. QED.'

questions.text: Calculations alone are sufficient for 'show that' questions—you don't need words.
questions.explanation: Brief explanatory statements help clarify your reasoning. 'By the factor theorem...', 'Since P(1) = 0...' show understanding.
questions.studyTip: Add brief phrases explaining why each step follows. It strengthens your argument.

questions.text: Including brief explanatory phrases like 'by the chain rule' or 'since x > 0' strengthens your response.
questions.explanation: This shows you understand the principles behind each step, not just the mechanics.
questions.studyTip: One line of reasoning can turn a borderline answer into full marks.

questions.text: Proof by induction just requires showing the base case and assuming it works for k.
questions.explanation: You need three parts: (1) Base case, (2) Assume true for n = k, (3) PROVE it for n = k + 1 using the assumption. Many students skip the actual proof step.
questions.studyTip: Base case → Assume for k → PROVE for k + 1 → Conclude by induction.

questions.text: Complete induction proofs require a base case, an inductive assumption, and proving the k + 1 case.
questions.explanation: All three components are mandatory. The proof for k + 1 must explicitly use the assumption for k.
questions.studyTip: Write: 'Assume true for n = k...' then '...therefore true for n = k + 1.'

questions.text: In the inductive step, you can prove P(k + 1) independently without using P(k).
questions.explanation: The whole point is using the assumption P(k) to prove P(k + 1). If you don't use it, you haven't done induction.
questions.studyTip: Your proof of P(k + 1) MUST reference and use your P(k) assumption.

questions.text: The inductive step must explicitly use the assumption P(k) to establish P(k + 1).
questions.explanation: This is what creates the 'chain' of logic from the base case to all positive integers.
questions.studyTip: Highlight where you use P(k). It should be the key step in your proof.

questions.text: Direct proofs can use specific numerical examples to prove general statements.
questions.explanation: Showing it works for specific numbers isn't a proof. You must work with general representations (e.g., 'let n = 2m + 1 for odd n').
questions.studyTip: Examples verify, they don't prove. Use variables for general arguments.

questions.text: Direct proofs require working with general expressions, not specific numerical examples.
questions.explanation: Express your general case (e.g., 'let n be odd, so n = 2k + 1') then derive the conclusion algebraically.
questions.studyTip: 'Let n = ...' is how you start. Work algebraically from there.

questions.text: The contrapositive of 'If P then Q' is 'If P then not Q'.
questions.explanation: The contrapositive is 'If not Q then not P'. It switches and negates both parts. This is logically equivalent to the original.
questions.studyTip: Contrapositive: switch hypothesis and conclusion, negate both.

questions.text: The contrapositive of 'If P then Q' is 'If not Q then not P'.
questions.explanation: Switch the positions of P and Q, then negate both. The contrapositive has the same truth value as the original.
questions.studyTip: P → Q is equivalent to ¬Q → ¬P. Know this cold.

questions.text: The cross product a × b gives the same result as b × a.
questions.explanation: The cross product is anti-commutative: a × b = −(b × a). Swapping the order changes the sign.
questions.studyTip: a × b = −b × a. Order matters for cross products.

questions.text: CAS technology can accurately compute cross products and reduce manual calculation errors.
questions.explanation: Cross products involve multiple terms and signs. Let CAS do the computation, but understand what it's calculating.
questions.studyTip: Use CAS for cross products. Check your setup is correct.

questions.text: Writing r = (1, 2, 3) + t(4, 5, 6) is the same as writing the vector (1 + 4t, 2 + 5t, 3 + 6t).
questions.explanation: The first is a vector equation of a line. The second is a point on that line. The equation requires the r = format with a point and direction vector.
questions.studyTip: Vector equation format: r = a + tb where a is a point, b is direction.

questions.text: A vector equation of a line must be written as r = a + tb with a point and a direction vector.
questions.explanation: Proper notation is essential. Just listing coordinates without 'r =' isn't a vector equation.
questions.studyTip: r = point + t(direction). This format every time.

questions.text: The distance between two skew lines is found by taking the difference of any two points on them.
questions.explanation: The shortest distance uses the formula involving the cross product of direction vectors. Random points give arbitrary distances, not the minimum.
questions.studyTip: Distance = |AP · (d₁ × d₂)| / |d₁ × d₂| where P and A are points on each line.

questions.text: Finding the distance between skew lines requires using direction vectors and the cross product formula.
questions.explanation: The perpendicular distance involves projecting onto the common perpendicular, found via the cross product.
questions.studyTip: Draw a diagram of skew lines. The formula finds the perpendicular distance.

questions.text: To find the equation of a plane, you only need two points on the plane.
questions.explanation: Two points define a line, not a plane. You need either three non-collinear points, or a point and a normal vector.
questions.studyTip: Plane needs: 3 points, OR point + normal, OR point + 2 direction vectors.

questions.text: The cross product of two direction vectors in a plane gives a normal vector to that plane.
questions.explanation: The cross product is perpendicular to both input vectors, hence perpendicular to the plane they define.
questions.studyTip: Two vectors in plane → cross product → normal → use for Cartesian equation.

questions.text: The area of a triangle formed by vectors a and b is |a × b|.
questions.explanation: That's the area of the parallelogram. The triangle area is half: ½|a × b|. Students often forget to divide by 2.
questions.studyTip: Triangle = ½|a × b|. Parallelogram = |a × b|. Don't mix them up.

questions.text: The area of a triangle with adjacent sides a and b is ½|a × b|.
questions.explanation: The cross product magnitude gives the parallelogram area. Halve it for the triangle.
questions.studyTip: Cross product → parallelogram area. Triangle is half that.

questions.text: The nth roots of unity are randomly distributed on the complex plane.
questions.explanation: The nth roots of unity are evenly spaced on the unit circle, separated by angles of 2π/n.
questions.studyTip: n roots, angle 2π/n apart, all on |z| = 1. Visualise the regular polygon.

questions.text: The nth roots of unity are evenly spaced around the unit circle, separated by 2π/n radians.
questions.explanation: They form the vertices of a regular n-gon centred at the origin on the unit circle.
questions.studyTip: Cube roots = triangle. Fourth roots = square. Fifth roots = pentagon. All on |z| = 1.

questions.text: When converting to polar form, you can use any angle that points to the correct position.
questions.explanation: The principal argument should be in (−π, π]. Angles outside this range should be converted, and all required solutions should be listed.
questions.studyTip: Principal argument is in (−π, π]. Know your quadrants for correct angles.

questions.text: When listing complex roots in polar form, include all distinct solutions with correct arguments.
questions.explanation: Students often miss solutions, especially when the argument is negative or involves multiples of π.
questions.studyTip: List all n roots. Check you have exactly n distinct angles.

questions.text: Plotting complex numbers on an Argand diagram is enough—labels are optional.
questions.explanation: Points should be labelled meaningfully (z₁, z₂, or with their values). Unlabelled dots may not earn marks.
questions.studyTip: Label every point you plot. z₁, z₂, or give the actual value.

questions.text: Complex number plots should have each point clearly labelled with its value or name.
questions.explanation: Labels show you know which point is which. They're especially important when multiple points are plotted.
questions.studyTip: Plotted point at (a, b) → label it as 'a + bi' or 'z₁'.

questions.text: CAS always gives complex numbers in the most useful form for your answer.
questions.explanation: CAS may give Cartesian when polar is asked, or vice versa. You must convert to the requested form.
questions.studyTip: Check what form the question wants. Convert your CAS output if needed.

questions.text: You must express complex number answers in the specific form requested by the question.
questions.explanation: Polar when polar is asked, Cartesian when Cartesian is asked. The form is part of the answer.
questions.studyTip: Question says 'polar form'? Give r(cos θ + i sin θ) or re^(iθ), not a + bi.

questions.text: Surface area of a solid of revolution is just the curved surface from the integral formula.
questions.explanation: Many students forget to add the circular ends. If the solid has flat ends, their areas must be included separately.
questions.studyTip: Curved surface from integral + circular ends (πr²) if they exist.

questions.text: When finding total surface area, you must add the areas of any flat circular ends to the curved surface area.
questions.explanation: The rotation integral gives curved surface only. Ends are separate circles with area πr².
questions.studyTip: Draw the solid. Does it have flat ends? Add πr² for each.

questions.text: The formulas for volume and surface area of revolution are essentially the same.
questions.explanation: They're different. Volume uses ∫πy² dx or ∫πx² dy. Surface area uses ∫2πy√(1 + (dy/dx)²) dx. Students mix these up.
questions.studyTip: Volume: π∫y² dx. Surface: 2π∫y√(1 + (y')²) dx. Know both.

questions.text: Surface area of revolution requires a different formula from volume, including the arc length factor.
questions.explanation: Surface area uses the arc length element √(1 + (dy/dx)²), making it more complex than volume.
questions.studyTip: Surface area has that square root factor. Don't use the volume formula by mistake.

questions.text: When integrating a parametric curve, you can use the parameter limits directly.
questions.explanation: You must convert: dx = (dx/dt)dt. The limits become parameter values, but the integrand must include dx/dt.
questions.studyTip: Parametric: ∫y dx = ∫y(dx/dt) dt. Don't forget the dx/dt factor.

questions.text: Converting a parametric integral requires multiplying by dx/dt and using parameter limits.
questions.explanation: This substitution transforms the integral into one in terms of the parameter t.
questions.studyTip: y dx → y·(dx/dt)·dt with new limits. Both the factor and limits change.

questions.text: All differential equations are solved by separating variables.
questions.explanation: Only separable equations can be solved this way. Other types require different techniques.
questions.studyTip: Separate if you can get all y's and dy on one side, all x's and dx on the other.

questions.text: Separable differential equations are solved by rearranging to ∫f(y) dy = ∫g(x) dx then integrating both sides.
questions.explanation: Get variables separated, integrate both sides, don't forget the constant, solve for y if required.
questions.studyTip: Separate → Integrate both sides → Include +C → Solve for y.

questions.text: If a question asks for dy/dx in terms of Q, giving it in terms of x and y is equivalent.
questions.explanation: You must express your answer in the specified variable. If it says 'in terms of Q', substitute to eliminate other variables.
questions.studyTip: Read what variable they want. Substitute to express in exactly that variable.

questions.text: When asked to express a derivative in terms of a specific variable, you must eliminate all other variables.
questions.explanation: This tests your ability to manipulate expressions. Use given relationships to substitute.
questions.studyTip: 'In terms of Q' means Q should be the only variable in your final answer.

questions.text: The standard deviation of the sample mean equals the population standard deviation.
questions.explanation: The standard deviation of the sample mean is σ/√n. Forgetting to divide by √n is a common error.
questions.studyTip: Sample mean has SD = σ/√n. Always divide by √n for sample means.

questions.text: The standard deviation of a sample mean is σ/√n, where n is the sample size.
questions.explanation: Larger samples give more precise estimates. The √n factor captures this.
questions.studyTip: More samples → smaller standard error. σ/√n shrinks as n grows.

questions.text: The standard deviation of X + Y equals the sum of their standard deviations.
questions.explanation: For independent variables, you add variances, not standard deviations. SD(X + Y) = √(Var(X) + Var(Y)).
questions.studyTip: Add VARIANCES, then square root. Never add standard deviations directly.

questions.text: For independent random variables, Var(X + Y) = Var(X) + Var(Y), then take the square root for SD.
questions.explanation: Variances add. Standard deviations don't. This is a frequent source of errors.
questions.studyTip: σ₁² + σ₂² = σ²ₜₒₜₐₗ, then √ to get SD. Not σ₁ + σ₂.

questions.text: A 95% confidence interval means there's a 95% probability the true mean is in that interval.
questions.explanation: The true mean either is or isn't in the interval. The 95% refers to the method: 95% of intervals constructed this way capture the true mean.
questions.studyTip: The interval is fixed, the mean is fixed. The 95% describes the process, not this interval.

questions.text: Confidence interval notation should use brackets like (a, b) to indicate the interval bounds.
questions.explanation: Proper notation shows you understand it's an interval of values, not just two numbers.
questions.studyTip: Write (lower, upper) with brackets. Present it as an interval.

questions.text: To halve the width of a confidence interval, you need to double the sample size.
questions.explanation: Width is proportional to 1/√n. To halve the width, you need to quadruple n. This question was poorly done.
questions.studyTip: Width ∝ 1/√n. Half width needs 4× sample size. Quarter width needs 16×.

questions.text: Reducing confidence interval width by half requires quadrupling the sample size.
questions.explanation: Since width depends on 1/√n, dividing width by 2 requires multiplying n by 4.
questions.studyTip: Width × 1/k → sample size × k². Know this relationship.

questions.text: A small p-value proves the alternative hypothesis is true.
questions.explanation: Small p-value = reject null hypothesis. It provides evidence for the alternative, but doesn't prove it absolutely true.
questions.studyTip: Reject null ≠ prove alternative. Use careful language about evidence and significance.

questions.text: Hypothesis test conclusions must reference the p-value and state whether to reject H₀.
questions.explanation: Compare p-value to significance level. State your conclusion with justification.
questions.studyTip: p < 0.05 → reject H₀. p > 0.05 → do not reject H₀. State both comparison and conclusion.

questions.text: Type II error probability is simply 1 minus the Type I error probability.
questions.explanation: Type I (α) and Type II (β) errors are not complementary. Finding β requires knowing the true parameter value under the alternative.
questions.studyTip: α and β are different calculations. β depends on the true value if H₁ is correct.

questions.text: Calculating Type II error requires finding the probability of not rejecting H₀ when H₁ is actually true.
questions.explanation: You need the critical value from H₀, then find P(not rejecting | H₁ true) using the actual distribution.
questions.studyTip: Find critical value under H₀. Calculate probability of being below it under H₁.

questions.text: When two curves meet, showing they share a point is enough to prove the join is smooth.
questions.explanation: Smooth join requires: (1) same point, (2) same gradient, and often (3) same second derivative. Just meeting isn't smooth.
questions.studyTip: Smooth = continuous + same derivative. Check both y and dy/dx match at the join.

questions.text: Verifying a smooth join requires showing curves have the same point AND the same gradient there.
questions.explanation: Continuity of the derivative ensures no 'corner'. Both conditions must be checked.
questions.studyTip: At x = a: y₁(a) = y₂(a) AND y₁'(a) = y₂'(a). Verify both.

questions.text: When a question says 'hence', you can solve it using any method you prefer.
questions.explanation: 'Hence' means use your previous result. Starting fresh ignores the intended approach and may lose marks.
questions.studyTip: 'Hence' = use what you just found. Don't start over with a new method.

questions.text: The word 'hence' indicates you should use your previous answer to solve the next part.
questions.explanation: It's guiding you to an efficient solution path. Your earlier work sets up the next part.
questions.studyTip: See 'hence'? Look back. How does your last answer help now?

questions.text: Drawing diagrams is only useful if the question explicitly asks for one.
questions.explanation: Diagrams help you visualise problems, especially in vectors, complex numbers, and calculus. They can guide your solution.
questions.studyTip: When stuck, draw it. A picture often reveals the approach.

questions.text: Sketching diagrams for vectors, complex numbers, or curves can clarify the problem and guide your solution.
questions.explanation: Visual representation helps identify relationships. Even a rough sketch can prevent errors.
questions.studyTip: Quick sketch → better understanding → fewer mistakes.

questions.text: If your calculation gives an answer, you should accept it as correct.
questions.explanation: Check if your answer makes sense. A negative probability, or a distance of 10⁵ km for a geometry problem, indicates errors.
questions.studyTip: Does your answer make sense? Negative lengths, huge numbers, or impossible values signal errors.

questions.text: Checking whether your answer is reasonable can help catch calculation errors.
questions.explanation: Probabilities between 0 and 1, positive distances, sensible magnitudes—quick checks catch mistakes.
questions.studyTip: Pause before writing final answer. Is this result plausible?

questions.text: Past exams are more useful than examiner reports for revision.
questions.explanation: Examiner reports reveal exactly where students went wrong and what assessors expect. They're invaluable for avoiding common mistakes.
questions.studyTip: Do past exams, then read the reports. Learn from everyone else's mistakes.

questions.text: Examiner reports highlight common errors and clarify what assessors expect in responses.
questions.explanation: They explain why students lost marks and show model solutions. Direct insight into assessment.
questions.studyTip: Reports tell you: 'Many students did X wrong.' Don't be one of them.
